conclusion: The particle with mass m and charge q enters the velocity selector N with a velocity v.
In the velocity selector, the electric field E and magnetic field B are perpendicular to each other.
For particles to pass through N undeflected, the electric force must equal the magnetic force, leading to E = vB.
The second particle has mass 2m and charge q.
The second particle starts from rest and is accelerated by the same particle accelerator M, gaining the same kinetic energy as the first particle when leaving M.
Let v' be the velocity of the second particle when it enters N; due to increased mass, v' will be different, but both particles have the same kinetic energy when leaving M.
The kinetic energy K of a particle is given by K = (1/2)mv^2.
For the second particle, K' = mv'^2, and since both particles have the same kinetic energy when leaving M, v'^2 = v^2/2, leading to v' = v/sqrt(2).
The deviation d is caused by the imbalance between the electric and magnetic forces.
The net force causing the deviation is F_net = q(vB - v'B).
The acceleration a due to this force is a = q(vB - v'B)/(2m).
The time t in the velocity selector can be approximated, and the deviation d is given by d = (1/2)at^2.
When the second particle exits N, it has kinetic energy due to both its motion and the work done by the electric field, given by E_k = mv'^2 + qEd.
Substitute v' = v/sqrt(2) into the kinetic energy equation to get E_k = (1/2)mv^2 + qEd.
The kinetic energy E_k of the second particle when it leaves N is E_k = (1/2)mv^2 + qEd.
